title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (September 16, 2019).

Factory workers at GM took to the picket lines in a nationwide strike, the UAW's largest work stoppage in more than a decade and one of the biggest walkouts at a private-sector employer in years.

Purdue Pharma filed for bankruptcy protection in a partial deal aimed at resolving lawsuits filed by municipalities and states accusing it of fueling the opioid crisis.

Boeing's board is expected to consider revamping the company's engineering department, following two deadly crashes of its 737 MAX airliner.

Investors are piling back into stocks and unwinding bets on haven assets, illustrating renewed faith that a resilient U.S. consumer can continue powering growth.

Warning signals in the junk-debt market indicate that investors are worried firms with high debt loads could be at risk even if the U.S. avoids recession.

Many Wells Fargo employees fired as the bank tried to deal with its fake-account scandal say they are effectively blacklisted from the industry.

Advertisers shelled out almost $100 million on U.S. TV commercials in and around the 2019 FIFA Women's World Cup, exceeding expectations.

The world is moving toward a new short-term lending benchmark to replace the troubled Libor, but companies don't seem to be in a rush to keep pace.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 16, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
